title: Flaneur's guide to London cafes
name: Flaneur's guide to London cafes
description:
A Map by Flaneur

Here's an attempt at plotting the cafes of London. This might take some time....  ;-)

properties.name: Aperture Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    On Museum street, opposite the main entrance to the British Museum

properties.name: Boulevard Deli
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur It\'s a deli, it\'s a take away and it\'s a small tucked in cafe. The food is probably the best of its kind in London, but the prices don\'t nearly reflect that. And the waitresses are gorgeous. Spoil yourself.

properties.name: Cafe Vergnano 1882
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur 62 Charing Cross Road, London, EnglandA classy traditional cafe providing a welcome break and pick-me-up from the rigours of perusing the music gear in Denmark Street and the bookshops of Charing Cross Road. Rumoured to make the best espresso in London. I can vouch for the branch in Ventimiglia; I\'ll let you know about London where competition for the title is stronger. But that shiny chrome Elektra Belle Epoque espresso machine leaves no doubt that they take their coffee-making seriously.

properties.name: Cafe in the Garden
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    Situated in the gardens of Bloomsbury Square. Russell Square Tube is nearest and several buses terminate here, including the 7 and 188.

properties.name: Carluccios
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur After a rumoured £100million facelift, the Brunswick Centre now even boasts a Carluccios. Expensive, but serious quality.

properties.name: Ciao Bella
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Actually an Italian restaurant on Lamb\'s Conduit Street, near Great Ormond Street Hospital and Mecklenburg Square. But it does great coffee, too.

properties.name: Clerkenwell Music
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  In Exmouth market, which despite rapid meeja gentrification does now have a market again. Jeremy has just put a coffee bar in his record shop, and it\'s great.

properties.name: Coffee, Cake and Kink
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur On Endell street, but with such small frontage you\'d miss it. Does what it says on the tin. Fantastic erotic art, photography and merchandise. And cake.

properties.name: Coram Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  The most wonderful cafe that seriously hardly anyone knows about. Attached to the Coram Foundling Museum, it too seems to evoke the decorum of a bygone era.

properties.name: Costa Coffee, Waterloo Railway Station
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  No, really. It\'s such a good place to people watch. Waterloo has great light. Get someone to guard a seat/table while you get the drinks in. All the staff have badges for their country of origin - do you know what the Georgian flag looks like?

properties.name: Crockatt & Powell
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Crockatt & Powell are an independent bookseller in Lower Marsh, Waterloo. Ok, they\'re not actually a cafe, but there are several nearby (including the wonderful Scooterworks). These guys are included because they\'re a great Flaneur hangout. Being independent means they can stock fascinating and unusual books that you will never find in the big high street bookshops that have major publishers breathing down their necks about what to stock and where to place things. Oh, and they\'re friendly guys, too.

properties.name: Epoca
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  Run by Frank, of Frank\'s further up the road, but a very different gaff. For my money Epoca make the best cappuccino in London.

properties.name: Franks
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur In the bustle towards Covent Garden at the Shaftesbury Avenue end of Neal street. More a caff than a cafe, but great sanwiches and tea, first rate fry-up, filling Italian food and the staff are brill.

properties.name: Great Court Cafe, British Museum
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    has to be seen to be believed... to be reviewed soon!

properties.name: Living Space
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    This internet cafe’s environmentally friendly design features include an eco-friendly air cooling system, computers and internet powered by solar panels on the grass roof, where rainwater is harvested and re-used to flush all the toilets. How eco is that?

properties.name: London Review Bookshop
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Is, of course, a bookshop, not a cafe. But it\'s a stunning one-of-a-kind bookshop, and a serious flaneur place to be. And there are cafes all around it, let\'s face it.

properties.name: Metropolitan Books
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Situated in Exmouth Market, Metropolitan is an independant bookshop, so there are more interesting and unusual books more readily found here than in any of the high street chains. Phil supports local authors as well as local shoppers which is cool, too. Metropoilitan is place most likely to bump into Magnus Mills, Jake Arnott, and... er... most of The Guardian and ITN.

properties.name: NFT Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur   The National Film Theatre cafe, under Waterloo Bridge, right on the South Bank, sit and watch the passers by, and check out the book stalls beneath the bridge.

properties.name: Neal's Yard
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Tucked away behind Neal Street and Seven Dials, New Age meets art meets world food. Really good vibe. Man.

properties.name: Night and Day Bar
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur On Southampton row amongst the hotels near the east side of Bloomsbury Square Gardens, this cafe actually is open night and day.

properties.name: Progresso
properties.description: Posted by FlaneurLooks just like a slick chain, with minimalist design and chic cool, and... it is. Except it was set up by Oxfam, and everything there is fairtrade. And that\'s a good thing. It\'s downstairs in the equally slick Thomas Neal shopping arcade, so it\'s almost like an underground refuge from the tourist consumer trauma that is Covent Garden. Almost. And yet... But the coffee\'s good. And the books beneath the seat/person holder receptacle thing is good. Just feels a bit weird crawling round on the floor looking through them....

properties.name: Scooterworks
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur   Scooterworks is probably the hippest cafe in London. Really. A 60s feel hangout for Waterloo and Lower Marsh locals, including writers, travellers and film makers, this cafe just happens to be the best place to get your Italian scooter serviced.

properties.name: St Martins Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  Look for a small set of steps leading down into the crypt below St Martins Church. A slightly odd feel to the cafe, but the crypt is huge, belying the entrance.

properties.name: The Poetry Place
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Down residential Betterton Street, off Endell Street, you\'d never know this cafe was here. This has to be the ultimate flaneur\'s hang out.

properties.name: Treadwell's
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Just off the strand in the heart of theatreland, Treadwells is actually a bookshop, but they\'ll make you cups of tea and sit you on their sofa. Another ultimate flaneur hangout, worthy of a big review very soon.

properties.name: Valtaro's
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Greasy spoon in the heart of Bloomsbury, and it\'s open on Sundays. Cracking fry-up, generous with their bacon, and the prices are good.
